items.title: Transcription vs Translation Sort
items.prompt: Sort each step into Transcription vs Translation.

cards.label: RNA polymerase uses DNA as a template to build mRNA
mRNA moves to a ribosome in the cytoplasm
tRNA matches anticodons to mRNA codons
A chain of amino acids forms a protein

items.title: DNA → RNA → Protein Flow

stimulus.text: Complete the model of how genetic information becomes a trait.

items.prompt: Select the correct answer for each box in the flow diagram.

items.title: Prokaryotic vs Eukaryotic Structure

stimulus.text: A student observes a cell with an electron microscope.

items.prompt: Which feature most strongly indicates the cell is prokaryotic?

choices.label: A nucleus surrounded by a membrane
DNA located in the cytoplasm without a nucleus

items.title: Photosynthesis Reactants
items.prompt: Which substances are required as reactants for photosynthesis to occur?

items.title: Photosynthesis vs. Cellular Respiration
items.prompt: Sort each statement into the correct biological process.

cards.label: Requires CO₂ and H₂O as reactants
Produces ATP for direct cell use

items.title: Biomolecule Monomers

stimulus.text: Large biological molecules (macromolecules) are assembled from smaller repeating subunits called monomers.

items.prompt: Which of the following are monomers that make up larger biological macromolecules? Select ALL that apply.

items.title: Control Group Identification

stimulus.text: A student tests whether fertilizer increases plant height. She grows 10 plants with fertilizer and 10 plants with only water, keeping all other conditions identical.

items.prompt: Which group of plants is the control group?

choices.label: The 10 plants grown with only water
Both groups together form the control
The student herself is the control

items.title: Energy Loss in Food Chains
items.prompt: Why does the amount of available energy decrease at each higher trophic level in a food chain?

choices.label: Organisms at higher trophic levels eat less food
Energy is lost as heat during metabolic processes
Higher-level organisms are always smaller in size
Sunlight cannot reach higher trophic levels

items.title: Natural Selection in a Population

stimulus.text: A population of beetles lives on dark tree bark. Green beetles are easily spotted and eaten by birds, while dark-brown beetles blend in and survive to reproduce.

items.prompt: Which outcome best describes what will happen to this beetle population over many generations?

choices.label: All beetles will eventually learn to avoid predators
The proportion of dark-brown beetles will increase over time
Green beetles will mutate to become dark-brown within one generation
The total population size will remain unchanged

items.title: Tt × Tt Cross: Dominant Phenotype %

stimulus.text: Tall (T) is dominant over short (t) in pea plants. Two heterozygous tall plants (Tt) are crossed.

items.prompt: What percentage of the offspring are expected to show the TALL phenotype? Enter a whole number.

items.title: Photosynthesis Evidence Pair

stimulus.text: A scientist places a plant in a sealed container with elevated CO₂. After 24 hours in sunlight, the CO₂ level drops and the plant's mass increases.

items.prompt:
Part A: Which process most directly explains the decrease in CO₂ inside the container?
Part B: Which molecule is the primary organic product of that process in the plant?
